skill.name: ChEMBL Database
skill.description: Query ChEMBL bioactive molecules and drug discovery data. Search compounds by structure/properties, retrieve bioactivity data (IC50, Ki), find inhibitors, perform SAR studies, for medicinal chemistry.
skill.summary: Query ChEMBL bioactive molecules and drug discovery data for medicinal chemistry research
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: All 175 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The static analyzer misidentified markdown code formatting (backticks) as shell command execution, documentation URLs as hardcoded network endpoints, and text patterns as weak cryptography. The actual Python code uses only the official ChEMBL Web Resource Client library for legitimate bioinformatics queries. This is a genuine scientific database integration skill with no malicious functionality.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: The markdown file contains Python code blocks showing pip installation commands with backticks. Backticks are Markdown syntax for inline code formatting, not shell command execution. No actual shell commands are executed by this skill.

SKILL.md contains extensive Python code examples in markdown code blocks and inline code spans for filter operators like __exact, __icontains. These are documentation, not executable code. The analyzer mistook markdown formatting for shell backticks.

This is a documentation file containing Python code examples. Backticks are markdown syntax for inline code. SMILES strings like 'CC(=O)Oc1ccccc1C(=O)O' are chemical notation using parentheses and equals signs, not shell operators.
Line 3 is the YAML frontmatter of SKILL.md. The static scanner incorrectly flagged text patterns. This skill makes no cryptographic operations - it only queries a public database API.
Line 235 uses pandas describe() for statistics. Line 313 filters molecules by properties (mw_freebase, alogp). Neither involve cryptography. The analyzer likely misidentified text patterns.
Lines 382-386 list URLs to official ChEMBL resources (ebi.ac.uk, github.com). These are documentation reference links, not code making network calls. No exfiltration or malicious network behavior.
These are legitimate documentation links to ChEMBL API docs, GitHub repository, and example notebooks. Standard documentation practice, not a security concern.
Lines extract ChEMBL IDs from query results using list comprehensions. This is standard data processing from API responses, not system enumeration or reconnaissance.
Line 24 lists 'Structure searches' as a legitimate use case for chemical substructure searching in a database. No network scanning or reconnaissance behavior exists.

content.user_title: Query ChEMBL bioactive molecules and drug discovery data
content.value_statement: Access the ChEMBL database to search compounds by structure and properties. Retrieve bioactivity measurements, find inhibitors, and perform structure-activity relationship studies for drug discovery research.
actual_capabilities: Search molecules by name, SMILES structure, or physicochemical properties
Retrieve bioactivity data including IC50, Ki, EC50, and Kd values
Find similar compounds and perform substructure searches
Query drug information, mechanisms of action, and clinical indications
Identify kinase inhibitors and other bioactive compounds
Export query results to pandas DataFrames for analysis
limitations: Rate limited by ChEMBL API fair usage policies
Cannot access local databases - only queries the ChEMBL web API
Data completeness depends on ChEMBL curation status

use_cases.title: Find Inhibitors for Drug Targets
use_cases.description: Search for potent inhibitors of specific targets like EGFR or kinases by querying bioactivity measurements.

use_cases.title: Analyze Drug-Target Interactions
use_cases.description: Retrieve drug mechanisms, indications, and activity profiles to understand compound-target relationships.

use_cases.title: Structure-Activity Relationship Studies
use_cases.description: Find similar compounds and analyze molecular properties to identify structure-activity patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Find Molecule by ID
prompt_templates.prompt: Get information about molecule CHEMBL25 (aspirin) from ChEMBL

prompt_templates.title: Search by Properties
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all molecules with molecular weight under 500, LogP under 5, and at most 10 hydrogen bond acceptors

prompt_templates.title: Query Bioactivity
prompt_templates.scenario: Find potent compounds for a target
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all EGFR inhibitors with IC50 values below 100 nM

prompt_templates.title: Structure Search
prompt_templates.prompt: Find compounds similar to aspirin (CC(=O)Oc1ccccc1C(=O)O) with 85 percent similarity

output_examples.input: Get information about aspirin from ChEMBL

best_practices: Use caching to respect rate limits when making repeated queries
Apply molecular weight and LogP filters early to reduce result sets
Always check the data_validity_comment field for potential issues
anti_patterns: Making rapid consecutive requests without respecting rate limits
Ignoring the pchembl_value normalization when comparing activities
Assuming all compounds in ChEMBL are experimentally verified

faq.question: What is ChEMBL?
faq.answer: ChEMBL is a manually curated database of bioactive molecules maintained by EBI, containing over 2 million compounds.

faq.question: Does this skill require API keys?
faq.answer: No, ChEMBL is a free public database. No authentication is required for basic queries.

faq.question: What activity values are available?
faq.answer: ChEMBL provides IC50, Ki, Kd, EC50, and other bioactivity measurements with standardized units.

faq.question: Can I search by chemical structure?
faq.answer: Yes, use SMILES strings for similarity searches and substructure matching.

faq.question: How are results returned?
faq.answer: Results are lazy-evaluated iterators. Convert to list() to force execution.

faq.question: What are good property filters for drug-likeness?
faq.answer: MW under 500, LogP under 5, HBA under 10, HBD under 5 follow Lipinski's rule of 5.
